title: Clark Haggans
text:
Clark Cromwell Haggans (born January 10, 1977) is a former <a href="American%20football">American football</a> <a href="linebacker">linebacker</a>. He was drafted by the <a href="Pittsburgh%20Steelers">Pittsburgh Steelers</a> in the fifth round of the <a href="2000%20NFL%20Draft">2000 NFL Draft</a>. He played <a href="college%20football">college football</a> at <a href="Colorado%20State%20Rams%20football">Colorado State</a> as a <a href="defensive%20end">defensive end</a>. Haggans played in the <a href="NFL">NFL</a> from 2000 through 2012, for the <a href="Pittsburgh%20Steelers">Pittsburgh Steelers</a>, <a href="Arizona%20Cardinals">Arizona Cardinals</a>, and <a href="San%20Francisco%2049ers">San Francisco 49ers</a>
Haggans earned a <a href="Super%20Bowl%20ring">Super Bowl ring</a> with the Steelers in <a href="Super%20Bowl%20XL">Super Bowl XL</a> against the <a href="Seattle%20Seahawks">Seattle Seahawks</a>.
College career.
Haggans played <a href="defensive%20end">defensive end</a> at <a href="Colorado%20State%20University">Colorado State University</a>. He was a productive pass rusher at Colorado State, where he <a href="walk-on%20%28sports%29">walked on</a> as a <a href="freshman">freshman</a>, eventually earning a <a href="Athletic%20scholarship">scholarship</a>. He was a teammate of former Steelers teammate <a href="Joey%20Porter">Joey Porter</a> and former Cincinnati Bengals linebacker <a href="Adrian%20Ross%20%28American%20football%29">Adrian Ross</a>. Haggans holds the Colorado State all-time sack record to this day, with 33 sacks recorded. He was inducted into the <a href="https%3A//csurams.com/honors/colorado-state-athletics-hall-of-fame%3Ftype%3Dsport">Colorado State University Athletics Hall of Fame</a> in 2015.
Professional career.
Pittsburgh Steelers.
The Steelers drafted Haggans out of the fifth round of the <a href="2000%20NFL%20Draft">2000 NFL Draft</a>. He became a regular <a href="Starting%20lineup">starter</a> at left outside linebacker in <a href="2004%20Pittsburgh%20Steelers%20season">2004</a> when the team released long-time starter <a href="Jason%20Gildon">Jason Gildon</a>.
Haggans recorded six <a href="quarterback%20sack">quarterback sack</a>s in 2004, and had nine sacks during the <a href="2005%20Pittsburgh%20Steelers%20season">2005</a> regular season. Haggans was second on the Steelers defense in tackles for <a href="Super%20Bowl%20XL">Super Bowl XL</a>, and also recorded a sack, helping the Steelers defeat the <a href="Seattle%20Seahawks">Seattle Seahawks</a>. In 2008, Haggans became an unrestricted free agent.
Arizona Cardinals.
On March 26, 2008, Haggans agreed to a one-year contract with the <a href="Arizona%20Cardinals">Arizona Cardinals</a>. He was placed on <a href="injured%20reserve">injured reserve</a> with a foot injury on December 19, ending his season. Without Haggans, the Cardinals would reach <a href="Super%20Bowl%20XLIII">Super Bowl XLIII</a>, but would lose to his old team, the <a href="Pittsburgh%20Steelers">Pittsburgh Steelers</a>, 27-23.
An <a href="unrestricted%20free%20agent">unrestricted free agent</a> in the 2009 offseason, Haggans was re-signed to a three-year contract by the Cardinals on March 17.
In 2009, he would go on to register 74 tackles, 5 sacks, and 2 forced fumbles in 16 games played. In 2010, he had 47 tackles, 5 sacks, and 1 forced fumble in 13 games.
In 2011, he reunited with <a href="Ray%20Horton">Ray Horton</a> who was hired as the new <a href="Arizona%20Cardinals">Arizona Cardinals</a> defensive coordinator to implement the <a href="Pittsburgh%20Steelers">Pittsburgh Steelers</a> style defense at Arizona.
He re-signed with the Cardinals on June 5, 2012, on a one-year deal.
San Francisco 49ers.
On September 2, 2012, Haggans agreed to a one-year contract with the <a href="San%20Francisco%2049ers">San Francisco 49ers</a>. The 49ers finished the <a href="2012%20NFL%20Season">2012 NFL Season</a> with an 11-4-1 record and reached <a href="Super%20Bowl%20XLVII">Super Bowl XLVII</a>, but lost 34-31 to the <a href="Baltimore%20Ravens">Baltimore Ravens</a>.
Personal life.
He participated in <a href="American%20football">football</a>, <a href="basketball">basketball</a> and track at <a href="Palos%20Verdes%20Peninsula%20High%20School">Palos Verdes Peninsula High School</a> in Southern California, earning three letters in each sport. During his freshman and sophomore years, Haggans was on football teams that went undefeated. In 1993 and 1994, he was named all-league as a <a href="tight%20end">tight end</a> and <a href="defensive%20tackle">defensive tackle</a>, while also earning all-division honors. In 1994, Haggans helped lead PVPHS' varsity team to a league title. He has a son named Damon and a daughter named Alianna. He majored in art at Colorado State.
Charity.
In 2012, Haggans became the first NFL player to support the Black Out Child Abuse Campaign. Black Out Child Abuse, Inc. is a 501(c)3 non-profit foundation, with offices in Westerville, OH, was founded in 2012 and serves families and organizations across the country; bringing education, assistance and support to those in need. Haggans wears blackout paint as opposed to the stick on in support of this cause.
